critique: This document is a military order from the Secretary of War during the Civil War. It directs troop movements and strategic positioning. Given the context of the Civil War, the document reflects a strong federal control as it pertains to military strategy and operations. There's no direct indication of ideological tilt in the traditional left-right sense, but the Union cause can be seen as more aligned with social inclusion (anti-slavery) compared to the Confederacy. The document doesn't directly address immigration, executive power in a broad sense, national security vs. civil liberties, economic regulation, or social inclusion beyond the implicit anti-slavery stance. Therefore, most axes will be scored as neutral.
